div1.p: Howard tries to resolve Reed's questions about the markings of the mosquitoes, but also states that there is still work to be done in the identifying process. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, November 16, 1900
div1.p: I have your letter of the 11th.

Culex fasciatustaeniatus, as I have pointed out, and as Mr. Theobald (who
is working up the mosquitoes of the world for the British Museum)
tells me he has concluded, is practically a tropical mosquito. But
it has never been sufficiently described. Perhaps when Theobald's
monograph appears we may know more about it, as English army surgeons
and colonists in tropical regions have sent him a large amount of
material. Mr. Coquillett tells me that the more he sees of Culex
fasciatus, the more he is inclined to adopt his first conclusion
that taeniatus was founded on a rubbed specimen of fasciatus. Both
have the fifth joint of the hind tarsi white. When he separated
the two forms recently, the one he referred to taeniatus (received
from New Orleans, as indicated in Bulletin 25) was founded upon two
defective female specimens, which appeared to have simple tarsal claws,
and for this reason he considered them distinct from fasciatus. The
examination, however, of other specimens from the same locality shows
that the front claws are toothed as in fasciatus, and a re-examina-
tion of the first two specimens shows that the remaining front tarsal
claws may likewise be toothed, but the under side of the claws
is so covered with dirt of some kind as to hide the teeth from view.
I believe that the specimen which you describe is fasciatus.

THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
LITTERA
SCRIPTA
MANET
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters

Whether taeniatus is a synonym, however, cannot be decided at
present.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, L.O. Howard Dr. Walter Reed, U. S. A.,
Camp Columbia, Quemados, Cuba.
